revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{spanish name 2|Moulitsas|Zúniga}} {{COI|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Markos Moulitsas | image = Moulitsas-army.jpg | caption = Markos "Kos" Moulitsas in the U.S. Army | birth_name = Markos Moulitsas Zuniga | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1971|09|11}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois]], U.S. | nationality = American | residence = [[Berkeley, California]], U.S. | other_names = Kos | alma_mater = [[Northern Illinois University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]])
[[Boston University School of Law]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) | known_for = [[Activism|Political activism]], blogging | occupation = Columnist, author, blogger | website = http://dailykos.com/ }} '''Markos Moulitsas Zúniga''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|ɑr|k|oʊ|s|_|m|uː|ˈ|l|iː|t|s|ə|s}}; born September 11, 1971), often known by his [[username]] and former military nickname "'''Kos'''" ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|oʊ|z}} {{respell|KOHZ|'}}), is the founder and publisher of [[Daily Kos]], a blog focusing on [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] politics in the United States. He co-founded [[SB Nation]], a collection of sports blogs, which is now a part of [[Vox Media]].{{cite web|title=Sportsblogs Inc. Scores $7 Million in 2nd Round|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=July 24, 2009|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/07/24/sportsblogs-inc-scores-7-million-in-2nd-round|accessdate=December 24, 2013}} He is also a weekly columnist at the Washington, D.C. newspaper ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]''.{{cite web|title=About Daily Kos|publisher=[[Daily Kos]]|url=http://www.dailykos.com/special/about2#mmz|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} Moulitsas currently resides in [[Berkeley, California]], with his two children.{{cite web|title=Today's Profile: Moulitsas Zuniga, Markos |publisher=[[H.W. Wilson Company]] |year=2007 |url=http://www.hwwilson.com/_home/bios/2006109895.htm |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427023846/http://www.hwwilson.com/_home/bios/2006109895.htm |archivedate=April 27, 2009 |df= }} ==Early life== Moulitsas was born in [[Chicago, Illinois]], to a [[Salvadoran]] mother and a [[Greeks|Greek]] father. He moved with his family to El Salvador in 1976, but later returned to the Chicago area in 1980 after his family fled when threats were placed on their lives by [[Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front|communist insurgents]] during the [[Salvadoran Civil War]]. As an adult, he has recounted his memories of the civil war, including an incident that occurred when he was 8 years old, in which he saw communist guerrillas murdering students who had been accused of collaborating with the government.{{cite web|last=Moulitsas|first=Markos|title=Mercenaries, war, and my childhood|publisher=[[Daily Kos]]|date=April 2, 2004|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2004/4/2/175739/8203|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} After graduating from [[Schaumburg High School]] in [[Schaumburg, Illinois]],{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Steve|title=The Net roots of Kos: Schaumburg High School|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=August 2, 2007|url=http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/technology_internetcritic/2007/08/kos-notes.html|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} he served in the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] from 1989 through 1992. He completed training at [[Fort Sill|Ft. Sill, Oklahoma]], and fulfilled his three-year enlistment as a [[Multiple rocket launcher|Multiple Launch Rocket System]] (MLRS) [[List of United States Army careers#Field Artillery Branch (FA)|Fire Direction Specialist]] while stationed in [[Bamberg]], Germany. By his own account, he "missed deploying to the Gulf War by a hair." Moulitsas has described the Army as "perhaps the ideal society – we worked hard but the Army took care of us in return."{{cite web|last=Moulitsas|first=Markos|title=The Soldier in Me|publisher=[[The American Prospect]]|date=April 16, 2006|url=http://prospect.org/article/soldier-me|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} Prior to enlisting in the Army, Moulitsas was a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. During the [[United States presidential election, 1988|1988 presidential election]], he served as a Republican [[precinct captain]] and assisted with the re-election campaign of [[Illinois's 6th congressional district|Illinois]] [[United States House of Representatives|Congressman]] [[Henry Hyde]]. However, during his time in the military Moulitsas began a transition in his political philosophy that would lead him to change his party affiliation from the Republican Party to the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. After leaving the army, he attended [[Northern Illinois University]] and graduated in 1996 with two bachelor's degrees, majoring in philosophy, journalism, and [[political science]].{{cite web|title=Northern Star Hall of Fame 2007 Class |publisher=The Northern Star |url=http://www.northernstar.info/alumni/hof2007.html |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106231920/http://www.northernstar.info/alumni/hof2007.html |archivedate=January 6, 2010 |df= }}{{cite web|last=Brick|first=Tricia|title=He's a Blogger on a Mission|publisher=''[[Boston University|Bostonia]]''|date=November 10, 2004|url=http://www.bu.edu/alumni/bostonia/2004/fall/partisan/index.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041215085709/http://www.bu.edu/alumni/bostonia/2004/fall/partisan/index.html|archivedate=December 15, 2004|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} While attending NIU, he wrote for the college newspaper, the Northern Star. Further illustrating the transition of his political philosophy, now a staunch supporter of gay rights,{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailykos.com/comments/148585/3662812#comment_3662812|title=My metric|work=Daily Kos|access-date=2017-10-28}} in 1993 while a freshman at NIU, he [http://northernstar.info/opinion/military-right/article_a690027e-94fb-5d86-bbe8-8f76abeeba77.html penned an opinion piece for the Northern Star] when Bill Clinton was working to lift the ban on homosexuals serving in the military denouncing such efforts in starkly homophobic terms.{{Cite news|url=http://northernstar.info/opinion/military-right/article_a690027e-94fb-5d86-bbe8-8f76abeeba77.html|title=Military right|work=Northern Star Online|access-date=2017-10-28|language=en}} As a writer, he also questioned NIU's policy of spending student fee money on athletic programs, generating a negative response from school officials, and waged an unsuccessful campaign to save the school's journalism program. In 2007, he was inducted into the Northern Star Hall of Fame, an honor bestowed by the newspaper's alumni association. After graduating from NIU, he attended the [[Boston University School of Law]] from 1996 to 1999, earning a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree. Moulitsas describes himself as a recovering Catholic, and says that while he has many problems with the Church, Salvadoran martyr and archbishop [[Óscar Romero]] is still his greatest hero and inspiration.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2004/8/3/141940/4587|title=Bush and Catholics|publisher=Dailykos.com|date=August 3, 2004|accessdate=May 9, 2016|archivedate=August 3, 2004|deadurl=unfit|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040803212623/http://www.dailykos.com/story/2004/8/3/141940/4587}} ==Daily Kos== {{main|Daily Kos}} After graduating from law school, Moulitsas moved to the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], where he worked as a project manager at a web development shop. He founded ''[[Daily Kos]]'' in May 2002, and has managed the blog as a full-time occupation since early 2004. ===Growth=== Since its creation Daily Kos has grown to become the largest liberal community blog in the United States, with over 2.3 million registered users and 8 million unique viewers per month as of July 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.quantcast.com/measure/dailykos.com|title=Dailykos.com Audience Insights|last=|first=|date=|website=www.quantcast.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-17}} The blog's popularity has attracted the attention of many Democratic senators, members of Congress, governors and candidates who have posted on the site, including [[United States Senate|Senators]] [[John Kerry]]{{cite web|last=Kerry|first=John|url=http://john-kerry.dailykos.com|title=John Kerry's Diary|publisher=John-kerry.dailykos.com|accessdate=April 13, 2010}} and [[Barbara Boxer]],{{cite web|last=Boxer|first=Barbara|url=http://barbara-boxer.dailykos.com|title=Barbara Boxer's Diary|publisher=Barbara-boxer.dailykos.com|accessdate=April 13, 2010}} [[Party leaders of the United States Senate|Senate Majority Leader]] [[Harry Reid]],{{cite web|last=Reid |first=Harry|url=http://harry-reid.dailykos.com|title=Harry Reid's Diary|publisher=Harry-reid.dailykos.com|accessdate=April 13, 2010}} [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Nancy Pelosi]],{{cite web|last=Democratic|first=House|url=http://house-democratic-leader-nancy-pelosi.dailykos.com|title=Nancy Pelosi's Diary|publisher=House-democratic-leader-nancy-pelosi.dailykos.com|accessdate=April 13, 2010}} former President [[Jimmy Carter]],{{cite web|last=Carter|first=Jimmy|url=http://jimmy-carter.dailykos.com|title=Jimmy Carter's Diary|publisher=Jimmy-carter.dailykos.com|accessdate=April 13, 2010}} and former President [[Barack Obama]].{{cite web|last=Obama|first=Barack|url=http://barack-obama.dailykos.com|title=Barack Obama's Diary|publisher=Barack-obama.dailykos.com|accessdate=April 13, 2010}} Daily Kos has also spawned an annual conference. The inaugural [[YearlyKos]] was held from June 8 to 11, 2006, in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. Guests included Harry Reid,{{cite web|url=http://www.netrootsnation.org/about/history|title=Netroots Nation: History|accessdate=May 9, 2016}} then-[[Governor of Virginia|Virginia Governor]] [[Mark Warner]],[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lxCJVKKuVNI YearlyKos: Mark Warner] June 28, 2006. and [[Democratic National Committee]] chairman [[Howard Dean]].[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oDrXpbX3gK8 YearlyKos Convention 2006 Keynote Speech by Howard Dean], June 10, 2006. The conference has since been renamed [[Netroots Nation]]. Moulitsas attended the [[California Democratic Party|California State Democratic]] convention in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] in March 2003 with [[Jerome Armstrong]] of [[MyDD]]. According to [[Glenn Reynolds]], founder of the conservative blog [[Instapundit]], he, Moulitsas and Armstrong may have been the first bloggers officially accredited at a political convention.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} ===Blackwater controversy=== In April 2004, Moulitsas and Daily Kos became the focus of controversy over a statement that he posted in the comments section of a blog post about [[Blackwater USA]] employees who were killed and mutilated in [[Fallujah]]:
Let the people see what war is like. This isn't an [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] game. There are real repercussions to Bush's folly. That said, I feel nothing over the death of [[mercenary|merceneries]] [sic]. They aren't in Iraq because of orders, or because they are there trying to help the people make Iraq a better place. They are there to wage war for profit. Screw them.{{cite web|last=Moulitsas|first=Markos|title=Every death should be on the front page|publisher=[[Daily Kos]]|date=April 1, 2004|url=http://www.dailykos.com/comments/2004/4/1/144156/3224/16#c16|accessdate=August 27, 2009}}
In a blog post the next day, Moulitsas defended and clarified his remarks:
My language was harsh, and, in reality, not true. Fact is, I did feel something. That's why I was so angry. I was angry that five soldiers—the real heroes in my mind—were killed the same day and got far lower billing in the newscasts. I was angry that 51 American soldiers paid the ultimate price for [[George W. Bush|Bush]]'s folly in Iraq in March alone. I was angry that these mercenaries make more in a day than our brave men and women in uniform make in an entire month. I was angry that the US is funding private armies, paying them $30,000 per soldier, per month, while the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]] tries to cut our soldiers' hazard pay.{{cite news|last=Epstein|first=Edward|title=Troops in Iraq face pay cut|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|date=August 14, 2003|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2003/08/14/MN94780.DTL|accessdate=November 5, 2009}} I was angry that these mercenaries would leave their wives and children behind to enter a war zone on their own violition ''[sic]''. So I struck back."
===Remarks about Hillary Clinton's 2008 presidential campaign=== On March 17, 2008, Moulitsas stated that Senator [[Hillary Clinton]], who was then involved in a protracted race against Senator [[Barack Obama]] for the [[2008 Democratic presidential primaries|Democratic presidential nomination]], "doesn't deserve fairness on this site" because she "fails the test of the guiding principles of this site" and because Clinton had "no reasonable chance of victory". He accused her of "formenting [sic] civil war in order to overturn the will of the Democratic electorate" and said Clinton's "only path to victory [...] is via coup by [[super delegate]]."{{cite web|last=Moulitsas|first=Markos|title=The Clinton civil war|publisher=[[Daily Kos]]|date=March 17, 2008|url=http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2008/3/17/12417/1285|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} His statement was precipitated by a "strike" conducted by several pro-Clinton diarists, even though none of these posters was paid or in any way officially linked to the site.{{cite news|last=Wheaton|first=Sarah|title=Blogtalk: Pro-Clinton Bloggers Boycott Kos|publisher=The New York Times|date=March 15, 2008|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/03/15/blogtalk-pro-clinton-bloggers-walk-out-of-kos|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} Moulitsas responded directly to the "strike" by saying that it was more like a "boycott", noting that "It's a big Internet, so I hope they find what they're looking for."{{cite web|last=Tapper|first=Jake|title=Clinton-Obama War Creates Serious Tensions at DailyKos|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=March 15, 2008|url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2008/03/clinton-obama-w.html|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} ===Electoral activity=== In 2004, Markos and [[Jerome Armstrong]] of [[MyDD]] founded [[BlogPAC]], a political action committee focused on progressive bloggers and politics online.[http://www.alternet.org/story/22233/the_blogfather "The Blogfather"], Alternet.org, June 15, 2005. In 2012, he was, by some measures, the most accurate major pundit to predict the result of the presidential election.{{cite web|title=Voteseeing|url=http://www.voteseeing.com/2012/11/2012-presidential-prediction-rankings.html|accessdate=December 6, 2012}} ==Consultant, author, and entrepreneur== During the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|United Kingdom general election]] in 2005, Moulitsas was hired by the British daily newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'' to write elections analysis for its weblog.{{cite news|last=Moulitsas|first=Markos|title=A different noise|publisher=The Guardian|date=September 28, 2004|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2004/sep/28/weblogs.comment|accessdate=August 27, 2009|location=London, UK}} Moulitsas was also a regular contributor to ''[[Newsweek]]'',{{cite web|author=Markos Moulitsas|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/70674|title=Markos Moulitsas's profile page at ''Newsweek''|publisher=Newsweek.com|date=September 11, 1971|accessdate=April 13, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222073820/http://www.newsweek.com/id/70674 |archivedate=December 22, 2007}} having been hired by the magazine for its 2008 presidential campaign coverage.{{cite web|last=Melber|first=Ari|title=Newsweek Hires Kos|publisher=[[The Nation]]|date=November 14, 2007|url=http://www.thenation.com/blogs/state_of_change/251606|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} He has also authored three books: ''[[Crashing the Gate|Crashing the Gate: Grassroots, Netroots, and the Rise of People-Powered Politics]]'' (co-written with [[Jerome Armstrong]]) and ''[[Taking On the System: Rules for Radical Change in a Digital Era]]''.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} Moulitsas is a fellow at the New Politics Institute,{{cite web|url=http://www.newpolitics.net|title=New Politics Institute|publisher=Newpolitics.net|accessdate=April 13, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330030009/http://www.newpolitics.net/|archivedate=March 30, 2010|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newpolitics.net/node/36|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061009035043/http://www.newpolitics.net/node/36|dead-url=yes|archive-date=October 9, 2006|title=Moulitsas profile|publisher=Newpolitics.net|accessdate=April 13, 2010}} a think tank of the [[New Democrat Network]], which was founded by [[Simon Rosenberg]] in 1996. The NDN's stated purpose is to help elect "[[centrism|centrist]]" Democrats, and is considered by many to be a successor to the centrist [[Democratic Leadership Council]] (DLC), an organization that Simon Rosenberg resigned from in 1996.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} In addition to political pursuits, Moulitsas co-founded [[SB Nation]], a network of sports blogs, with Tyler Bleszinski (of [[Athletics Nation]]) in 2003.{{cite web|title='Kos'-Founded SB Nation Picks Up $5M|publisher=Dow Jones Financial Information Services|date=January 14, 2009|url=https://www.fis.dowjones.com/article.aspx?ProductIDFromApplication=32&aid=DJFVW00020090114e51e0008f&r=Rss&s=DJFVW|accessdate=August 27, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721124314/https://www.fis.dowjones.com/article.aspx?ProductIDFromApplication=32&aid=DJFVW00020090114e51e0008f&r=Rss&s=DJFVW|archivedate=July 21, 2011|df=mdy-all}} The network now covers all major American leagues (MLB, NBA, NFL, and NHL), as well as dozens of colleges and other specific sports like golf, cycling, and ultimate fighting.{{cite news|last=Hart|first=Kim|title=A New Arena for Hard-Core Sports Fans|publisher=The Washington Post|date=February 9, 2009|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/02/08/AR2009020801725.html|accessdate=August 27, 2009}} In 2011, SB Nation became [[Vox Media]] and began expanding, raising capital to acquire and develop other blog networks.{{cite web|url=https://thenextweb.com/media/2012/03/12/building-a-digital-media-empire-sb-nation-and-the-verge-owner-vox-media-raises-17-million|last=Wauters |first=Robin|title=Building a digital media empire: SB Nation and The Verge owner Vox Media raises $17 million|publisher=The Next Web|date=March 12, 2012|accessdate=December 24, 2013}} Vox Media now owns eight media brands covering news, lifestyle, technology, sports, and lifestyle.{{Cite news|url=https://www.voxmedia.com/a/go-deeper/about|title=About {{!}} Vox Media: Go Deeper|last=Media|first=Vox|date=2018-07-13|work=VoxMedia.com|access-date=2018-07-20}} In March, 2018, Moulitsas announced the launch of Civiqs, a polling and data operation that tracks opinions on candidates, issues, and elected officials.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2018/3/12/1748087/-Announcing-Civiqs-the-coolest-thing-I-ve-helped-build-since-Daily-Kos|title=Announcing Civiqs: the coolest thing I've helped build since Daily Kos|work=Daily Kos|access-date=2018-07-15}} ==Bibliography== *''[[Crashing the Gate|Crashing the Gate: Netroots, Grassroots, and the Rise of People Powered Politics]]'' (Chelsea Green, 2006); {{ISBN|1-931498-99-7}} *''[[Taking On the System: Rules for Radical Change in a Digital Era]]'' ([[Penguin Group]], 2008); {{ISBN|0-451-22519-8}} *''American Taliban: How War, Sex, Sin, and Power Bind Jihadists and the Radical Right'' ([[Polipoint Press]], 2010); {{ISBN|1-936227-02-9}} ==See also== * [[Libertarian Democrat]] ==References== {{Infobox person | image = Misty_Upham.png | caption = Upham in 2013 | name = Misty Upham | birth_name = Misty Anne Upham | birth_date = {{birth date|1982|7|6}} | death_date = {{death date and age|2014|10|5|1982|7|6}} | birth_place = [[Kalispell, Montana|Kalispell]], [[Montana]], U.S. | spouse = | death_place = [[Auburn, Washington|Auburn]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], U.S. | children = | occupation = Actress | yearsactive = 2002–2014 }} '''Misty Anne Upham''' (July 6, 1982 – October 5, 2014) was a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] actress. She attracted critical acclaim for her performance in the 2008 film ''[[Frozen River]]'', for which she was nominated for an [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Supporting Female]]. She also appeared in ''[[Jimmy P: Psychotherapy of a Plains Indian]]'' and ''[[August: Osage County]]''. ==Early life== Misty Anne Upham was born on July 6, 1982, in [[Kalispell, Montana]], and raised in [[Auburn, Washington]]. A [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]], she was a member of the [[Blackfeet Indian Reservation|Blackfeet Nation]].Schmidt, Rob. [http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2013/09/30/misty-upham-reflects-filming-jimmy-p-benicio-del-toro-151514 " Blackfeet Actress Misty Upham On Filming 'Jimmy P.' with Benicio Del Toro."] ''[[Indian Country Today Media Network]]'', September 30, 2013; accessed February 1, 2014. She was reportedly sexually abused, assaulted and gang-raped, first as a child and then later in life as an upcoming actress in Hollywood.{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Rick|title=The Painful Life and Mysterious Death of Misty Upham|url=http://archive.seattleweekly.com/home/955560-129/the-painful-life-and-mysterious-death|accessdate=October 6, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Misty Upham Raped at 2013 Golden Globes?|url=https://www.hollywoodlanews.com/misty-upham-raped-2013-golden-globes/|work=Hollywood LA News|date=November 10, 2017|accessdate=November 14, 2017|quote=My daughter, Misty Upham, was a victim of rape by a Weinstein Executive in 2013 at the Golden Globe Awards.}}{{cite web|last1=Upham|first1=Charles|title=The recent backlash with regard to Harvey Weinstein’s sexual allegations|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10208399015252536&set=a.1022977994287.4048.1820347633&type=3&theater|date=October 15, 2017|accessdate=November 14, 2017|quote= I pleaded with her to press charges since she still has the torn green dress she wore (Photo Above) with the DNA all over it.}} Both Upham and family members reported that she suffered from depression and the severe [[PTSD|after effects of these traumas]]. ==Career== Upham's film credits include ''[[Expiration Date (film)|Expiration Date]]'', ''[[Edge of America]]'', ''[[Skins (2002 film)|Skins]]'' and ''[[Skinwalkers (2002 film)|Skinwalkers]]''. In 2010, she appeared on HBO's ''[[Big Love]]''. In 2013, she played a major supporting role in [[Arnaud Desplechin]]'s ''[[Jimmy P: Psychotherapy of a Plains Indian]]'', selected in competition for the [[Palme d'Or]] at the 66th [[Festival de Cannes]]. She played the housekeeper Johnna in ''[[August: Osage County (film)|August: Osage County]]'', and played Liz in ''[[Cake (2014 film)|Cake]]''. ==Death== On Sunday, October 5, 2014, Upham left her sister's apartment on the [[Muckleshoot|Muckleshoot Reservation]] in [[Auburn, Washington]], on foot. The following weekend, her family announced via [[Facebook]] and other media that she had not been heard from since then and that they were concerned for her welfare, citing past [[mental health]] problems.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/misty-upham-actress-missing|title=August: Osage County Actress Misty Upham Missing|work=PEOPLE.com|accessdate=13 October 2014}}{{cite news|title=Actress Misty Upham still missing in Seattle area|url=http://nativetimes.com/index.php/life/people/10682-actress-misty-upham-still-missing-in-seattle-area|accessdate=October 15, 2014|work=Native Times|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=October 15, 2014}}{{cite news|title=Actress Misty Upham Missing; Last Seen in Muckleshoot, WA|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2014/10/10/actress-misty-upham-missing-last-seen-muckleshoot-reservation-wa-157305|accessdate=10 October 2014|publisher=Indian Country Today Media Network|date=10 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.king5.com/story/news/local/2014/10/10/misty-upham-missing-washington/17060193/|title=Family: Actress Misty Upham missing in Washington|date=10 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=13 October 2014}} A spokesman for the Auburn Police Department told [[CNN]] that police had not opened an investigation and were not regarding Upham as a [[missing person]] at that time. He confirmed that family members had contacted police on several occasions in the past year to report Upham missing but that she had been located and determined to be safe within a few days in each previous case.{{cite news|last1=Griggs|first1=Brandon|title=Actress' disappearance baffles family|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/10/13/showbiz/movies/missing-actress-misty-upham/index.html|accessdate=October 13, 2014|work=[[CNN]]|date=October 13, 2014}} On October 16, 2014, Misty Upham's body was found by a small search party organized by her family and other members of the Muckleshoot Tribe.{{cite news|title=Misty Upham's Father Says Her Death Was an Accident, but Alleges Mistreatment by Police|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2014/10/17/misty-uphams-father-says-her-death-was-accident-alleges-mistreatment-police-157412|accessdate=19 October 2014|publisher=Indian Country Today Media Network|date=17 October 2014|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141019225153/http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2014/10/17/misty-uphams-father-says-her-death-was-accident-alleges-mistreatment-police-157412|archivedate=19 October 2014|df=}} Her body was found at the bottom of a cliff in a wooded area,{{cite news|first1=Steve|last1=Miletich|first2=Paige|last2=Cornwell|title=Body found in Auburn believed to be missing actress|url=http://blogs.seattletimes.com/today/2014/10/body-found-in-white-river-believed-to-be-missing-actress/|accessdate=October 16, 2014|work=[[Seattle Times]]|date=October 16, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/10/misty-upham-dead-frozen-river-august-osage-county-missing-police-853408/ |title=Misty Upham Found Dead: Family Of ‘Frozen River’ Actress Says Police Uncooperative In Search |work=Deadline Hollywood |date=October 16, 2014 |accessdate=October 16, 2014}} just a short distance from where the family had previously searched. Members of the search party believe her death was an accident; that she fell off the cliff in the dark and that her life could have been saved had there been a prompt and thorough search. Citing lack of action on the part of the Auburn police, and alleging past abuse of Misty Upham by members of the Auburn Police Department, Upham's family released a statement that reads in part:
"''But the real tragedy is this could have been prevented on a lot of levels. We pleaded with the Auburn Police to help us find Misty but Commander Stocker made the decision that Misty did not fit the criteria of the Washington State Endangered Missing Persons Plan. This became a point of contention between us and the Auburn PD. In a statement he gave to the press he said Auburn PD doesn't have any evidence that Misty is actually missing. He went on to say that Misty packed her belonging and left her apartment. This was an inaccurate statement. We believe that Commander Stocker had animosity against Misty due to a previous encounter.''"
"''Now press reports are saying that Auburn police department found Misty. The truth is the Native American community formed a search party and found her after several days of searching without the help of the Auburn PD''".
On December 3, 2014, the [[King County, Washington|King County]] [[Medical Examiner]] released a report stating Misty Upham had died of blunt-force injuries to her head and torso on October 5, 2014, the day she disappeared.{{Cite web|title = Misty Upham Cause of Death Revealed: Actress Died of Blunt-Force Injuries|url = https://uk.yahoo.com/movies/misty-upham-cause-of-death-revealed-actress-died-104331350857.html#|website = uk.yahoo.com|accessdate = 2015-12-27}} The medical examiner stated that "the manner of her death – whether by foul play, suicide or accident – could not be determined."{{Cite web|title = Misty Upham: the tragic death and unscripted life of Hollywood's rising star|url = https://www.theguardian.com/global/2015/jun/30/misty-upham-native-american-actress-tragic-death-inspiring-life|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-12-27|first = Kristen Millares Young in|last = Seattle}} In late October, 2016, the upcoming release of a documentary on Upham was announced. ''11 Days - The Search for Misty Upham'' investigates her disappearance and death, and the search for her led by her family in what they report was the absence of police support.[http://11days-documentary.magix.net/ 11 Days - The Search for Misty Upham] - 2016 independent documentary about the disappearance, death, and search for Misty Upham. It is scheduled to appear at Native American film festivals, notably in the broader context of the ongoing issue of [[Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women (Canada)|Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women (MMIW)]].[https://www.evensi.us/13th-red-nation-film-festival-laemmmle-monica-4-plex/185900907 Red Nation Film Festival Native Cinema] 21/10/2016 02:22 "13th Red Nation Film Festival will have a 'Spotlight' on Indigenous Murder and Missing Women as part of Native Women in Film & Television Initiative. With an introduction to this very important film '11 Days The Search for Misty Upham.' A Red Nation Film Festival Official Selection Spotlight"[http://www.rednationff.com/ Red Nation Film Festival Awards Show] 2016 Official Selections. Accessed 25 Oct 2016. On October 15, 2017, in the wake of the [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations]], Upham's father, Charles Upham, [[Weinstein effect|went public]] with allegations that his daughter was raped by a member of Weinstein's production team at the same Golden Globes ceremony where she was honored, and that other members of Weinstein's team had not only witnessed the rape but had cheered the rapist on. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Director ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | rowspan=3| 2002 | ''[[Skins (2002 film)|Skins]]'' | Mrs. Blue Cloud | [[Chris Eyre]] | |- | ''[[Auf Wiedersehen, Pet]]'' | Dawn | [[Paul Seed]] | TV Series (2 episodes) |- | ''[[Skinwalkers (2002 film)|Skinwalkers]]'' | Nina | Chris Eyre | TV movie |- | rowspan=2| 2003 | ''[[Dreamkeeper]]'' | Chief's Daughter | [[Steve Barron]] | TV movie |- | ''Edge of America'' | Shirleen | Chris Eyre | TV movie |- | rowspan=1| 2006 | ''[[Expiration Date (film)|Expiration Date]]'' | Charlie's Mother | [[Rick Stevenson]] | |- | rowspan=1| 2008 | ''[[Frozen River]]'' | Lila Littlewolf | [[Courtney Hunt]] | [[American Indian Film Festival]] for Best Supporting Actress

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} '''Molly Ockett''' (died August 2, 1816, Andover, Maine), was a Native American woman of the [[Abenaki]] nation who lived in the regions of northern [[New Hampshire]] and [[Maine]] during colonial times. Her Abenaki name meant "Singing Bird", but she was also baptised and given the name Mary Agatha. This was most likely pronounced as "Molly Agat" or "Molly Ockett" by Abenaki speakers.
She was born sometime between 1725 and 1744 and was said to be a daughter of the chief of her tribe. Her date of death is given as August 2, 1816.
This could be not true, but she was said to have married a minute man in the Revolutionary War by the name of Edward Marden. They had a kid who was named Edward E Marden Jr., and this is theorized because of the photo of her grandsons Nathaniel Richmond Marden and Chapin Kidder Marden. Nathaniel and Chapin look and have a lot of physical features a Native American would have. They are both tall, (Nathaniel being 6 ft and 1 in), and having curly hair.
Molly was reputed to be a skilled healer<ref>{{cite web|title=Who Was MollyOckett?|url=http://www.mollyockettdays.com/who-was-mollyockett.html|website=MollyOckett Day|publisher=Bethel Area Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=15 July 2016|location=[[Bethel, Maine]]}}</ref> and wise woman with a singular sense of humor. She was well known by European settlers in the area and her name is still attached to numerous locales in the [[Androscoggin River]] valley and surrounding territory.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Molly Ockett and Her World | work = Bethel Historical Society | accessdate = 2013-12-22 | url = http://www.bethelhistorical.org/Molly_Ockett_and_Her_World.html }}</ref>
Molly Ockett Middle School in [[Fryeburg, Maine]], is named after her,<ref>{{Cite web | title = Mona Polacca - North America at Evergreen | accessdate = 2013-06-16 | url = http://www.evergreen.edu/events/springcolloquium/monapolacca.htm }}</ref> and [[Bethel, Maine]], hosts an annual summer festival titled 'MollyOckett Days'.<ref>{{Cite web | title = MollyOckett Days | accessdate = 8 June 2014 | url = http://www.mollyockettdays.com }}</ref>

The '''"Monsters of Ecatepec"''' is the mediatic given to a pair of mexican serial killers conformed by '''Juan Carlos Hernández''' <ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.letraroja.com/prostituta-y-subnormal-la-novia-del-monstruo-de-ecatepec/|title=Prostituta y "subnormal": la novia del Monstruo de Ecatepec|last=|first=|date=10 October 2018|work=La Silla Rota|access-date=19 October 2018|language=Spanish|trans-title=Prostitute and "subnormal": the Monster of Ecatepec´s girlfriend}}</ref>(1985, [[Lázaro Cárdenas, Michoacán|Lázaro Cárdenas]], [[Michoacán]]) and '''Patricia Hernández'''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://diario.mx/Nacional/2018-10-15_ff3ff2be/monstruo-de-ecatepec-se-comia-a-sus-victimas-en-carne-asada/|title='Monstruo de Ecatepec' se comía a sus víctimas en carne asada|last=Excélsior|work=El Diario de Juárez|access-date=2018-10-20|language=es-MX}}</ref> (1980, .[[Lázaro Cárdenas, Michoacán|Lázaro Cárdenas]], [[Michoacán]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newsbeezer.com/chileeng/the-monster-of-ecatepec-and-other-serial-killers-in-mexico/|title="The Monster of Ecatepec" and other serial killers in Mexico|website=newsbeezer.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-20}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.la-prensa.com.mx/policia/356676-los-monstruos-de-ecatepec-son-originarios-de-lazaro-cardenas|title=Los "monstruos" de Ecatepec son originarios de Lázaro Cárdenas|last=|first=|date=13 October 2018|work=La Prensa|access-date=19 October 2018|language=Spanish|trans-title=The "monsters" of Ecatepec are originated from Lázaro Cárdenas}}</ref> The case also received the names of ''"The House of Horror"''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/internacional/2018/10/06/5bb8eec9e5fdead95d8b45b6.html|title=La casa de los horrores mexicana|last=Sánchez Olmos|first=Pablo|date=6 October 2018|work=ELMUNDO|access-date=2018-10-20|language=es|trans-title=The Mexican House of Horror}}</ref> or ''"The Butchers of Ecatepec"''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.la-prensa.com.mx/policia/356283-audiencia-del-carnicero-de-ecatepec-en-vivo|title=¡Que nunca salga de la cárcel! Piden en audiencia del "Carnicero de Ecatepec"|last=|first=|date=11 October 2018|work=La Prensa|access-date=2018-10-20|trans-title=Never free down them from jail! Demanded in Butcher of Ecatepec´s audience}}</ref>. Active in [[Ecatepec de Morelos]], [[State of Mexico]], from 2012 to 2018. The pair are suspected to have commited between 10 and 20 murders, and have also confessed to cannibalize the bodies of their victims .<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/mexico-serial-murder-couple-claim-20-killings-10805932|title=Mexico serial murder couple claim 20 killings|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=2018-10-20|language=en-US}}</ref> The pair were apprehended on October 4th, 2018 when transporting human remains in a baby stroller.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/1028805/mexico-news-murder-pet-food-Juan-Carlos-N|title=Serial killer murdered 20 women before feeding remains to pets, court told|last=McGrath|first=Ciaran|date=2018-10-09|work=Express.co.uk|access-date=2018-10-20|language=en}}</ref>
== Background == They were both born in Lázaro Cárdenas, Michoacán, within a five year age gap. Juan Carlos' mother was a single mother, allegedly she often dressed him as a girl, brought men to her house and forced her son to watch her sexual encounters. Also, he declared that in his childhood he suffered sexual abuse by another woman who at the time was his caretaker.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://lasillarota.com/metropoli/asi-es-el-sombrio-facebook-del-monstruo-de-ecatepec-juan-carlos-ecatepec-feminicidios-asesino/251179|title=Así es el "sombrío" Facebook del "Monstruo de Ecatepec"|last=Gutiérrez González|first=Rodrigo|date=9 October 2018|work=La Silla Rota|access-date=19 October 2018|language=Spanish|trans-title=The "dark" Facebook page of the "Monster of Ecatepec"}}</ref> When he was 10 years-old he fell from the stairs and suffered a [[Traumatic brain injury|severe traumatic brain injury]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.proceso.com.mx/555382/el-efecto-gatillo-en-el-monstruo-de-ecatepec|title=El "efecto gatillo" en el "monstruo de Ecatepec" - Proceso|date=2018-10-15|work=Proceso|access-date=2018-10-20|language=es-MX}}</ref> Patricia Martínez was born in a poor family, and was manipulative. She was diagnosed with a border intelligence disorder linked to [[intellectual disability]]. She was a prostitute at the time.<ref name=":0" />
The couple met in 2008, when Patricia worked as waitress in a restaurant from the State of Mexico, of which Juan Carlos was a regular client. They initiated a relationship and, although he presumed to be an "assassin", she decided to move with him.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.eluniversal.com.mx/columna/hector-de-mauleon/nacion/el-monstruo-y-ella|title=El Monstruo y ella|last=De Mauleón|first=Héctor|date=2018-10-15|work=El Universal|access-date=2018-10-20|language=es|trans-title=The Monster and her}}</ref> The couple procreated four children during their 10 year realtionship. They opened a family business where they sold clothing, perfume and cellphones.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-45806103|title=Qué se sabe del "monstruo de Ecatepec" y su pareja, los asesinos seriales de mujeres que vendían los restos de sus víctimas|last=Nájar|first=Alberto|date=2018-10-10|work=BBC News Mundo|access-date=2018-10-20|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Crimes == Their first victim, according to Patricia's declaration, was a 22-year-old woman who Juan Carlos lured with job promises. In their house, Hernández conducted her to their bathroom where he raped, beheaded and dismembered her. Martínez kept their children outside the house while the murder occurred. After the murder, Martínez partially cooked the body and ate it with her husband.<ref name=":1" /> Their second victim was a teen girl who lived next to them, who suffered an [[Addiction to drugs|inhalants addiction]] , they allegedly lured her with promises of wealth. Like the first victim she was also raped, beheaded and dismembered in their bathroom. Patricia cooked the victim's body in [[Chili con carne|chilli]].<ref name=":1" />

{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{refimprove|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Nora Barnacle | image = James-Giorgio-Nora-Lucia-Joyce-Paris-1924.jpg | image_caption = Paris 1924: Clockwise from top left – James Joyce, Giorgio Joyce, Nora Barnacle, Lucia Joyce | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1884|3|21}} | birth_place = [[Galway]], [[County Galway]], Ireland | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1951|4|10|1884|3|21}} | death_place = [[Zürich]], Switzerland | spouse = {{marriage|[[James Joyce]] |1931|1941}} Eloped in 1904}}
'''Nora Barnacle''' (21 March 1884 – 10 April 1951) was the [[Artistic inspiration|muse]] and wife of Irish author [[James Joyce]].
Barnacle and Joyce had their first romantic assignment on a date celebrated worldwide as the ‘Bloomsday’ of his modernist novel ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]'', a book that she did not, however, enjoy. Their sexually explicit letters have aroused much curiosity, especially as Joyce normally disapproved of coarse language, and they fetch high prices at auction.
Barnacle was played by [[Susan Lynch]] in the 1999 bio-pic ''[[Nora (2000 film)|Nora]]''.
==Early life== {{redirect|Michael Bodkin|the GAA referee|Michael Bodkin (referee)}} Barnacle was born in [[Galway]] [[workhouse]] on 21 March 1884.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://civilrecords.irishgenealogy.ie/churchrecords/images/birth_returns/births_1884/02698/1993624.pdf|title=General Registrar's Office|website=IrishGenealogy.ie|access-date=24 March 2017}}</ref> Her entry in the birth register, which gives her first name as "Norah", is dated 22 March. Her father, Thomas Barnacle, a baker in [[Connemara]], was an illiterate man who was 38 years old when she was born. Her mother, Annie Honoria Healy, was 28 and worked as a dressmaker.
Between 1886 and 1889, Barnacle's parents sent her to live with her maternal grandmother, Catherine Mortimer Healy. During these years, she began studies at a convent, eventually graduating from a national school in 1891. In 1896, Barnacle completed her schooling and began to work as a porteress and laundress. In the same year, her mother threw her father out for drinking and the couple separated. Barnacle went to live with her mother and her uncle, Tom Healy, at 4 Bowling Green, Galway.
In 1896, at age 12, Barnacle fell in love with a teenager named [[Michael Feeney (schoolteacher)|Michael Feeney]], who died soon after of [[typhoid]] and [[pneumonia]]. In a dramatic coincidence, another boy she loved, Michael Bodkin, died in 1900 – causing some of her friends to call her "man-killer." Joyce later based the final short story in ''[[Dubliners]]'', "[[The Dead (short story)|The Dead]]", on these incidents. It was rumoured that she sought comfort from her friend, budding English theatre starlet, Laura London, who introduced her to a Protestant named [[Willie Mulvagh]]. In 1903, she left Galway after her uncle learned of the affair and friendship, and went to [[Dublin]] where she worked as a [[maid|chambermaid]] at Finn's Hotel (later the name of the hotel was used as the title for a posthumously-published collection of ten short narrative pieces written by Joyce, ''[[Finn's Hotel]]'', in 2013).<ref name="guardian">[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/jun/14/james-joyce-collection-published James Joyce's 'last undiscovered' collection to be published | Books | theguardian.com]</ref>
==Relationship with Joyce== Barnacle met Joyce on 10 June 1904 while still in Dublin and they had their first romantic liaison on 16 June. Joyce later chose 16 June 1904 as the date for the setting for his novel ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]'' and the date has come to be known and celebrated around the world as [[Bloomsday]]. The 1904 rendezvous began a long relationship that eventually led to marriage in 1931<ref>{{cite news | title=James (Augustine Aloysius) Joyce Biography (1882–1941) | url =https://www.biography.com/people/james-joyce-9358676 | accessdate = 8 June 2017 }}</ref> and continued until Joyce's death.
Barnacle's and Joyce's relationship was complex. They had different personalities, tastes and cultural interests. Of their first meeting, she recalled: "I mistook him for a Swedish sailor – His electric blue eyes, yachting cap and [[Plimsoll shoe|plimsolls]]. But when he spoke, well then, I knew him at once for just another Dublin [[jackeen]] chatting up a country girl."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Introducing Joyce: a graphic guide|last1=Norris |first1=David |last2=Flint |first2=Carl |publisher=Icon Books Ltd|year=1994|isbn=978-184831-351-4|location=London|pages=46}}</ref> The numerous erotic letters they exchanged suggest they loved each other passionately.<ref name="Maddox - Guardian 2004">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/jul/09/books.booksnews|title=Ah yes – but what ever happened to Nora's side of the correspondence?|last=Maddox|first=Brenda|date=8 July 2004|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref> These are also of interest because of Joyce’s lifelong dislike of swearing and crude language.<ref>://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/3877209.stm</ref> Joyce seems to have admired and trusted her, and Barnacle clearly loved Joyce and trusted him enough to agree to leave Ireland with him for the Continent. In anticipation of the move to Paris, she began studying French and Barnacle cooked English puddings at Joyce's request during their travels.
In 1904, Barnacle and Joyce left Ireland for continental Europe and the following year set up house in [[Trieste]] (at that time in [[Austria-Hungary]]). On 27 June 1905, Nora Barnacle gave birth to a son, Giorgio and later to a daughter, [[Lucia Joyce|Lucia]], on 26 July 1907. A miscarriage in 1908 coincided with the beginning of a difficult time for both. Though she remained by his side, and the couple were legally married in London in 1931, she complained to her sister both about his personal qualities and his writings.
In these letters to her sister, she said he drank too much and wasted too much money. As for his literary activity, she lamented that his writings were obscure and lacking in sense. She was always fiercely proud of him, although she occasionally expressed impatience at his meetings with other artists and admitted she would have preferred him had he been a musician—in his youth, he was a talented singer—rather than a writer.
Lucia's mental illness, which became acute in the early 1930s, posed another challenge to the couple's relationship. Nora believed the condition required hospitalisation, which Joyce opposed. They brought in many specialists, and Lucia was for a time the patient of [[Carl Jung]]. She was diagnosed with [[schizophrenia]] and admitted to a clinic in 1936. Her father visited her there often, but not her mother. As Nora's biographer Brenda Maddox recorded, 'Lucia was rarely out of Nora's mind. Because she had aroused Lucia's most florid schizophrenic reactions, Nora was not allowed to accompany Joyce on his ritual Sunday afternoon visits to Ivry. Not only did this exclude her from any contact with her daughter, it also required her to spend much of each week arranging for someone to accompany Joyce, who could not easily go alone... Joyce liked to portray himself as safe from Lucia's violence, as if he was the only other permitted inhabitant of her private world. Yet once when Giorgio went with his father, Lucia saw them and cried, 'Che bello! Che bello!' then lunged and tried to strangle them.' As Maddox also noted, 'There is no record that Nora ever saw her daughter again.'{{cn|date=June 2018}}
==Later life and death==
After Joyce's death in [[Zurich]] in 1941, Nora decided to remain there. She died in Zurich of [[acute renal failure]] in 1951, at age 67.
==Maddox biography== {{main|Nora (2000 film)}}
In 1988, Nora Barnacle was the subject of a biography by [[Brenda Maddox]], ''Nora: A Biography of Nora Joyce''.<ref>{{cite book|first= Brenda|last= Maddox|title=Nora: Biography of Nora Joyce|publisher= Hamish Hamilton |year=1988|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QtRaAAAAMAAJ|isbn=9780241123850}}</ref>
This in turn was made into a film in 1999, directed by Pat Murphy and starring [[Susan Lynch]] and [[Ewan McGregor]].
==Auction of letter from Joyce to Nora== In 2004, an erotic letter from Joyce to Barnacle sold at [[Sotheby's]] for £240,800, a record amount for a modern-day letter at auction.<ref>{{cite news | title=Joyce letter smashes sale record | date=8 July 2004 | publisher =BBC News | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3877209.stm | accessdate = 17 August 2007 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.census.nationalarchives.ie/search/results.jsp?census_year=1901&surname=Barnacle&firstname=&county=Galway&townland=bowling+green&ded=&age=&sex=&search=Search&relationToHead=&religion=&education=&occupation=&marriageStatus=&birthplace=&language=&deafdumb=&marriageYears=&childrenBorn=&childrenLiving= 1901 Census of Ireland, entry on Bowling Green, Galway for Barnacle family. (Specific listing: Barnacle, Norah. Bowling Green, Galway North, Urban, Galway. Age 18, Female)] * [http://www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai000807914/ PDF of scanned image off 1901 Census data, listing household members at Barnacle house.] * [http://www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai000807909/ PDF of scanned image off 1901 Census data, listing house and building return for Barnacle house and buildings.]
{{James Joyce|state=expanded}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Norman Hilberry | birth_name = Horace van Norman Hilberry | image = File:Szilard and Hilberry.jpg | image_size = | caption = Norman Hilberry (left) with [[Leo Szilard]] at [[Stagg Field]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1899|03|11}} | birth_place = [[Cleveland, Ohio]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1986|3|28|1899|03|11}} | death_place = [[Phoenix, Arizona]] | residence = | citizenship = American | nationality = | ethnicity = | field = [[Physics]] | work_institution = [[New York University]]
[[Argonne National Laboratory]]
[[University of Arizona]] | alma_mater = [[Oberlin College]], A.B.
[[University of Chicago]] Ph.D. | doctoral_advisor = | thesis_title = Extensive cosmic-ray showers and the energy distribution of the primary cosmic rays | thesis_year = 1941 | doctoral_students = | known_for = Director of [[Argonne National Laboratory]] | author_abbreviation_bot = | author_abbreviation_zoo = | prizes = | religion = | footnotes = }} '''Norman Hilberry''' (March 11, 1899 – March 28, 1986) was an American physicist, best known as the director of the [[Argonne National Laboratory]] from 1956 to 1961. In December 1942 he was the man who stood ready with an axe to cut the [[scram]] line during the start up of [[Chicago Pile-1]], the world's first [[nuclear reactor]] to achieve [[Criticality (status)|criticality]]. ==Biography== Horace van Norman Hilberry was born in [[Cleveland, Ohio]], on March 11, 1899. He received his [[Bachelor of Arts]] (A.B.) degree from [[Oberlin College]] in 1921, and then became an assistant in physics at the [[University of Chicago]]. In 1925 he became an instructor in physics at [[Washington Square College]] in New York, where he rose to become an [[assistant professor]] in 1928.{{cite web |url=https://www.aip.org/history/acap/biographies/bio.jsp?hilberryn |title=H. van Norman Hilberry |publisher=Array of Contemporary American Physicists |accessdate=December 25, 2015 }} He earned his [[Doctor of Philosophy]] (Ph.D.) from the University of Chicago in 1941, writing his thesis on "Extensive cosmic-ray showers and the energy distribution of the primary cosmic rays".{{cite web |url=https://catalog.lib.uchicago.edu/vufind/Record/4279558 |title=Extensive cosmic-ray showers and the energy distribution of the primary cosmic rays |publisher=University of Chicago |accessdate=December 25, 2015 }} In 1941, Hilberry joined what would become the [[Manhattan Project]], the effort to create an [[atomic bomb]] during [[World War II]]. He moved to the University of Chicago to help [[Arthur H. Compton]] in any way possible.{{sfn|Compton|1956|p=80}} Hilberry became associate director of Compton's Metallurgical Project.{{sfn|Compton|1956|p=83}} On December 2, 1942, he was present for the start up of [[Chicago Pile-1]], the world's first [[nuclear reactor]] to achieve [[Criticality (status)|criticality]]. Because of fears that the reaction could "run away", Hilberry stood ready with an axe to cut the [[scram]] line, a manila rope connected to control rods that could quickly shut the reactor down.{{cite web |url=http://www.cfo.doe.gov/me70/manhattan/cp-1_critical.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122183641/http://www.cfo.doe.gov/me70/manhattan/cp-1_critical.htm |archivedate=November 22, 2010 |title=CP-1 Goes Critical |publisher=Department of Energy}}{{cite web |url=http://public-blog.nrc-gateway.gov/2011/05/17/putting-the-axe-to-the-scram-myth/comment-page-1/ |accessdate=December 25, 2015 |title=Putting the Axe to the 'Scram' Myth |publisher=United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission |first=Tom |last=Wellock }} He was also present for the start-up of the [[X-10 Graphite Reactor]] in November 1943, and the reactors at the [[Hanford Engineer Works]] the following year. He returned to the Metallurgical Laboratory in Chicago in 1945. Hilberry became assistant director of the [[Metallurgical Laboratory]] in 1943. On July 1, 1946, the Metallurgical Laboratory became [[Argonne National Laboratory]], the first designated National Laboratory, with [[Walter Zinn]] as director,{{cite web|url=http://www.uchicago.edu/features/how_the_first_chain_reaction_changed_science/ |accessdate=19 December 2015 |first=Steve |last=Koppes |title=How the First Chain Reaction Changed Science|publisher=The University of Chicago}} and Hilberry as associate director. He became the deputy director in 1949, and the director in June 1956, on Zinn's departure. He was the first director of Argonne's International School of Nuclear Science and Engineering, an important part of the [[Eisenhower Administration]]'s [[Atoms for Peace]] program, from 1955 to 1956.{{cite journal |url=http://jnm.snmjournals.org/content/5/5/397.full.pdf |journal=Journal of Nuclear Medicine |title=Norman Hilberry |issn=0161-5505 |date=May 1, 1964 |volume=5 |issue=5 |pp=397–398 |accessdate=December 25, 2015 }} He stepped down in November 1961, and was replaced by [[Albert Crewe]].{{sfn|Holl|Hewlett|Harris|1997|pp=205–208}} He remained at Argonne as a senior scientist until 1964, when he accepted an appointment as Professor of Nuclear Engineering at the [[University of Arizona]]. He retired and became a [[professor emeritus]] in 1985. Hilberry was the recipient of the [[American Nuclear Society]]'s Arthur Holly Compton Award, and received a citation for meritorious service from the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]].{{cite news |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |title=Norman Hilberry: Physicist Directed Atomic Laboratory |date=April 5, 1986 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/04/05/obituaries/norman-hilberry-physicist-directed-atomic-laboratory.html |accessdate=December 25, 2015 }} He was president of the American Nuclear Society from 1965 to 1966. He was a member of the board of directors of the Atomic Industry Forum from 1961 to 1968, of the Advisory Committee on US Policy Toward the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] in 1962, and of the [[National Academy of Sciences]]' Advisory Committee to the United States Office of Emergency Preparedness from 1968 to 1973. He died from complications arising from [[influenza]] on March 28, 1986, at the Humana Desert Hospital in [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. He was survived by his wife Ann and daughter Joan. His papers are in the University of Chicago Library.{{cite web |url=https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/scrc/findingaids/view.php?eadid=ICU.SPCL.NHILBERRY |title=Guide to the Norman Hilberry Papers 1961 |accessdate=December 25, 2015 }} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book |last=Compton |first=Arthur |authorlink=Arthur Compton |year=1956 |title=Atomic Quest |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |oclc=173307 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Holl |first=Jack M. |title=Argonne National Laboratory, 1946–96 |first2=Richard G. |last2=Hewlett |authorlink2=Richard G. Hewlett |first3=Ruth R. |last3=Harris |publisher=University of Illinois Press |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-252-02341-5 |oclc=36074441 |ref=harv }} ==External links== {{commons}} *{{cite web |url=http://manhattanprojectvoices.org/oral-histories/norman-hilberrys-interview-1985 |title=Norman Hilberry's Interview |year=1985 |publisher=Manhattan Project Voices |accessdate=December 26, 2015 }} {{portal bar|Biography|Nuclear technology|World War II}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hilberry, Norman}} [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:American physicists]] [[Category:Manhattan Project people]] [[Category:Scientists from Cleveland]] [[Category:Oberlin College alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:New York University faculty]] [[Category:University of Arizona faculty]] [[Category:Argonne National Laboratory people]] [[Category:Deaths from influenza]]

revision.text:
'''Olga Dmitrievna Kudrina''' (c. 1890-1944) was a shamaness among the Reindeer [[Evenks|Evenki]] of northern [[Inner Mongolia]] along the [[Amur River]]'s Great Bend (today under the jurisdiction of [[Genhe]], [[Hulunbuir]]). She was accepted as an arbiter between the various Reindeer Evenki groups, helping to defuse conflicts between families when a member of one murdered a member of the other; after her death, the egalitarian hunters were left with no widely accepted shaman or other authority figure, and conflicts among them escalated into a chain of serious cases of blood revenge.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|2007|p=167}}</ref>
==Background and early life== The Reindeer Evenki comprise three groups: the Mohe, Cigančen, and Three-River (Gunačen).<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|2007|p=169}}</ref> Originally, Filipp Vasil’evič Sologon was the shaman of the Mohe group, while Kudrina belonged to the Gunačen in the south.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|2007|p=171}}</ref> She came from a family of shamans; her grandmother, uncle Vasilij Jakovlevič Kudrin, and cousin Innokentij Ivanovič Kudrin were all shamans.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|1999|p=383}}</ref> It was common for many shamans to come from the same family; however, the position was not necessarily transmitted lineally.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|1999|p=382}}</ref>
Kudrina's responsibilities as a shamaness included aiding in the hunt, curing the sick, and watching over the souls of the deceased; she was required to be knowledgeable about spirits and religion.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|1999|p=379}}</ref> She started on the path to becoming a shamaness in 1923, in a dream in which she claimed to have seen the spirit of her predecessor and received his knowledge.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|1999|p=382}}</ref> During this time she was reported to have gone deep into the forest, remaining there for two weeks without fire or food.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|1999|p=383}}</ref>
==Death and legacy== Sologon died in 1942, leading Kudrina to take over responsibility for his group. This meant that she had to make arduous treks over the [[Greater Khingan]] mountains to reach the hunting grounds of the Mohe group. Conflicts broke out more frequently in these years due to the [[Mengjiang|Japanese occupation]], pitting pro-Japanese Evenki against anti-Japanese Evenki; in 1944, about fifty people from the Mohe group fled back to [[Russia]] as a result.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|2007|p=171}}</ref> Kudrina died later that same year, leaving behind two other shamans: her cousin Kudrin, and Njura Kaltakun, neither of whom had widely accepted authority among all the groups.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|2007|pp=171–172}}</ref> Blood revenge spread after her death, but older hunters made efforts to halt the cycle, seeing the threat it posed to their survival as an ethnic group, and Kaltakun would finally be able to bring the blood feuds to a halt in the early 1950s.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|2007|pp=174–175}}</ref>
Kudrina had no children of her own.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|1999|p=391}}</ref> She was survived by her adopted son, Victor Kudrin.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|2007|p=173}}</ref> She also took Anatolij Makarovič Kajgorodov (1927–1998), a member of a Russian Cossack family with whom the Reindeer Evenki frequently traded, as a godson; he would go on to become a well-known ethnographer of the Tungusic peoples.<ref>{{harvnb|Heyne|2007|p=176}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|3}}
==Sources== *{{citation|first=F. Georg|last=Heyne|title=The Social Significance of the Shaman among the Chinese Reindeer-Evenki|journal=Asian Folklore Studies|volume=58|issue=2|pages=377–395|url=http://nirc.nanzan-u.ac.jp/publications/afs/pdf/a1299.pdf|year=1999|doi=10.2307/1179101}} *{{citation|first=F. Georg|last=Heyne|title=Notes on Blood Revenge among the Reindeer Evenki of Manchuria|journal=Asian Folklore Studies|volume=66|year=2007|pages=165–178|url=http://nirc.nanzan-u.ac.jp/publications/afs/pdf/a1600.pdf|issue=1/2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kudrina, Olga}} [[Category:1890s births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:Siberian shamanism]] [[Category:People from Hulunbuir]] [[Category:Tungusic peoples]] [[Category:Shamans]] [[Category:Female religious leaders]]
