{{Infobox television | show_name = The Martin Short Show | image = | caption = | genre = [[Sitcom]] | runtime = 30 minutes | company = [[Martin Short|Dolshor Productions]]
[[Universal Television|NBC Productions]] | creator = [[Martin Short]]
Paul Flaherty
Michael Short | developer = | presenter = | starring = Martin Short
[[Jan Hooks]]
[[Noley Thornton]]
Zack Duhame
[[Andrea Martin]]
[[Brian Doyle-Murray]] | composer = Ed Alton | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = United States | language = [[English language|English]] | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 8 (5 unaired) | list_episodes = | producer = | executive_producer = Martin Short | director = [[Eugene Levy]] | location = | camera = | network = [[NBC]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = September 15 | last_aired = October 1, 1994 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = }} '''''The Martin Short Show''''' is an American television [[sitcom]] that aired from September 15 until October 1, 1994 on [[NBC]]. ==Overview== The series focuses on Marty Short, a comedian who tries to balance his work life as a sketch show host, and his home life with his wife and children. == Cast == *[[Martin Short]] - Marty Short *[[Jan Hooks]] - Meg Harper Short *[[Noley Thornton]] - Caroline Short *Zack Duhame - Charlie Short *[[Andrea Martin]] - Alice Manoogan *[[Brian Doyle-Murray]] - Gary ==Episodes== {{Empty section|date=November 2013}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0108851|The Martin Short Show}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martin Short Show (1994 TV series), The}} [[Category:1990s American sitcoms]] [[Category:NBC network shows]] [[Category:Television series by Universal Television]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:1994 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1994 American television series endings]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of people]] {{comedy-tv-prog-stub}}

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Utut Adianto |office = Deputy Speaker of [[People's Representative Council]] |term_start = 20 March 2018 |office1 = Member of [[People's Representative Council]]
from [[Central Java]] |term_start1 = 1 October 2009 |image = Wakil Ketua DPR Utut Adianto.jpg |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1965|3|16|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]] |party = [[PDI-P]] }} {{Infobox chess biography |name = Utut Adianto |image = Utut Adianto Wahyuwidayat.jpg |birthname = Utut Adianto Wahyuwidayat |country = {{IDN}} |title = [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] (1985) |peakrating = 2615 (January 1998) |FideID = 7100019 }} '''Utut Adianto Wahyuwidayat''' (born 16 March 1965 in [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]]) is an Indonesian [[chess]] [[International Grandmaster|Grandmaster]] and politician. He is Indonesia's top-rated player of all-time with an [[Elo rating]] of 2566, and also serves as the deputy speaker of the [[People's Representative Council]] since March 2018. ==Career== Utut Adianto learned the game of chess at the age of six. He won the Jakarta Junior Championship at the age of 12. In 1982, he won the [[Indonesian Chess Championship]]. He was awarded the GM title in 1986, becoming at the time the youngest Indonesian to do so at the age of 21 years. Since then, [[Susanto Megaranto]] has become a GM at the age of 17 years. Between 1995 and 1999 Adianto maintained an [[Elo rating]] over 2600.{{cite news|title=Profil Drs Utut Adianto|url=https://www.viva.co.id/siapa/read/106-drs-utut-adianto|accessdate=12 April 2018|work=VIVA|language=id}} In 1999, he participated in the [[FIDE World Chess Championship 1999|FIDE Knock-out world chess championship in Las Vegas]], losing to [[Daniel Fridman]] in the first round.{{cn|date=April 2018}} Utut Adianto is chairman of the Indonesian Chess Federation ([[PERCASI]]).{{cite web|title=PERSONALIA PB PERCASI|url=https://www.pbpercasi.com/p/pelantikan-pengurus-besar-percasi-masa.html|publisher=Percasi|accessdate=12 April 2018}} With Machnan R. Kamaluddin, Eka Putra Wirya and Kristianus Liem, he founded a chess school in Indonesia, which has produced several national players. In 2005, Adianto was awarded the title of [[FIDE]] Senior Trainer.[http://www.globalchessacademy.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=24&Itemid=42 Global Chess Academy - FIDE Certified Trainers] On 9 May 2009, he was elected to the [[People's Representative Council]], the lower house of Indonesia's [[Bicameralism|bicameral]] parliament. He became deputy speaker of the body on 20 March 2018.{{cite news|last1=Erdianto|first1=Kristian|title=Utut Adianto Resmi Menjabat Wakil Ketua DPR RI|url=https://nasional.kompas.com/read/2018/03/20/15390331/utut-adianto-resmi-menjabat-wakil-ketua-dpr-ri|accessdate=8 April 2018|work=KOMPAS|date=20 March 2018|language=id}}{{cite news|title=House to Inaugurate New Deputy Speaker|url=http://en.metrotvnews.com/national-en/GNGMRovk-house-to-inaugurate-new-deputy-speaker|accessdate=12 April 2018|work=MetroTV News}} ===Sample game=== In the game below, Adianto beats four-time U.S. chess champion [[Alexander Shabalov]]:{{cite web |url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1015192 |title=Alexander Shabalov vs Utut Adianto (1993) |work=Chessgames.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303194804/http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1015192 |archivedate=3 March 2016}} *White: Shabalov *Black: Adianto Game played in New York, 1993, [[Caro-Kann Defense]] 1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.e5 Bf5 4.Nc3 e6 5.g4 Bg6 6.Nge2 c5 7.Be3 Nc6 8.dxc5 Nxe5 9.Nf4 a6 10.Qe2 Nf6 11.O-O-O Be7 12.Bg2 Nexg4 13.Nfxd5 exd5 14.Nxd5 Nxd5 15.Qxg4 O-O 16.Bxd5 Qc7 17.f4 Rad8 18.Rhe1 Qa5 19.Bf2 Bxc5 20.Re5 Qa4 21.Bb3 Rxd1+ 22.Kxd1 Rd8+ 23.Kc1 Qb4 24.Be1 Qd4 25.a3 Bxa3 26.c3 Qb6 27.Qh4 Bd6 28.Rd5 Re8 29.f5 Qxb3 30.Rxd6 Bxf5 31.Rd2 Qa2 0-1 ==References== == External links == * {{chessgames player|id=16249}} *[http://www.sekolahcatur.com Sekolah Catur Utut Adianto (chess school)] - in Indonesian {{DEFAULTSORT:Adianto, Utut}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Balinese people]] [[Category:Chess coaches]] [[Category:Chess grandmasters]] [[Category:Chess Olympiad competitors]] [[Category:Indonesian chess players]] [[Category:Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle politicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the People's Representative Council, 2014]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Jakarta]] [[Category:Chess players at the 2006 Asian Games]]

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''[[Venerable]] Stylianus of Paphlagonia''' was born to a wealthy family between the 4th and 6th centuries in Paphlagonia, [[Asia Minor]]. Upon his parents' death he donated all the family wealth and entered into [[monastic life]] with great devotion.
After some time in the [[monastery]] he gained a reputation for piety and excellence in the spiritual life, however, the jealousy of the other [[monk]]s drove Stylianus to pursue the solitary life of a [[hermit]].
Stylianus gradually gained a reputation for sanctity with the local people who came to him increasingly for aid with their spiritual and temporal needs. He became well known as a healer of physical and mental illnesses. His great affection for children also inspired parents to ask his prayers for their offspring and he became known as a protector and healer of the young.
Venerable Stylianus is commemorated on 26 November in the [[Eastern Orthodox]], [[Roman Catholic]] and [[Eastern Catholic]] Churches.[http://www.oca.org/FSlives.asp]
==See also== {{Portal|Saints}} *[[Daniel the Stylite]] *[[God: Sole Satisfier]]
==References== *[http://www.oca.org/FSlives.asp Orthodox Church in America] *[http://forums.catholic.com/showthread.php?t=197609&page=6%20-%20146k Catholic Answers: November 26]

'''White Matlack''' (October 7, 1745; [[Haddonfield, New Jersey]] – January 7, 1824) to Elizabeth Martha Burr Haines and Timothy Matlack: a couple that had both lost their first spouses. His grandparents were William Matlack and Mary Hancock; and Henry Burr and Elizabeth Hudson. His siblings were Sybil, Elizabeth, Titus, Seth, Josiah and [[Timothy Matlack]]. He was a New York Quaker and abolitionist.
He married Mary Hawhurst<ref>Some sources have Hawxhurst</ref> on March 6, 1768.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.threerivershms.com/marriageH.htm|title=Names of Persons for whom MARRIAGE LICENSES Were issued by the Secretary of the Province of New York Previous to 1784|last=O'Callaghan|first=E. B. |year=1860|publisher=Weed, Parsons and Company|page=175|accessdate=2009-08-25}}</ref> They had four children; White, Timothy, Mary, and Hannah.<ref>http://boards.ancestry.myfamily.com/surnames.matlack/92.2/mb.ashx</ref>
White was a watchmaker and silversmith in New York City from around 1769 to 1775. In 1775, he also worked in Philadelphia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~silversmiths/makers/silversmiths/143737.htm |title=White Matlack |last=Voss |first=Wm Erik |year=2005 |publisher=Rootsweb |accessdate=2009-08-25 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100409024210/http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~silversmiths/makers/silversmiths/143737.htm |archivedate=2010-04-09 |df= }}</ref> Then he ran a brewery located not far from the [[Fraunces Tavern]]. By the 1780s he moved into steel manufacturing.<ref name="pbs">[https://www.pbs.org/opb/historydetectives/investigations/709_miniature.html George Washington Miniature] [[History Detectives]]</ref>
In 1782, he and [[Isaac Howell]] signed a document titled ''The memorial and remonstrance of Isaac Howell and White Matlack, in behalf of themselves, and others, who have been disowned by the people called Quakers, &c''.<ref>http://nla.gov.au/nla.cat-vn3365947</ref> White and his brother Timothy had been [[wikt:disown|disown]]ed by Orthodox [[Quakers]] for their support of the [[American Revolution]]. They formed a group with others called the [[Society of Free Quakers]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Harker|first=John Balderston|title=Betsy Ross's Five Pointed Star|year=2004|chapter=Chapter 6: Betsy Ross, Quaker Rebel|url=http://mybetsyross.com/chapter6.html}}</ref>
In 1786, he signed a letter to the Senate and assembly of the State of New York, against the shipping of African slaves through the port of New York.<ref name="pbs"/>
Three years later he became a member of the [[New York Manumission Society]]. In 1787, the society founded the [[African Free School]].
He died at Bay Side, near [[Flushing Bay, New York|Flushing]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ba044ancestry.com/MATLOCKMISC/DeathRecordsandObits/NewYorkDeathRecordsandObits.htm|title=MATLOCK-MEDLOCK DEATH RECORDS AND OBITS|accessdate=2009-08-25}}</ref> on Long Island, aged 80.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jervey|first= Elizabeth Heyward |date=Jan 1954|title=Marriage and Death Notices from the City Gazette of Charleston (Continued)|journal=The South Carolina Historical Magazine|publisher= South Carolina Historical Society|volume=55|issue=1|pages=48–51|jstor=27565947|quote=Died on Long Island, near New York, White Matlack, Esq. a patriot of the Revolution, aged 80.}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite book|url=http://chestofbooks.com/home-improvement/furniture/Colonial-Furniture-America/XI-Clocks-Part-5.html|title=Colonial Furniture In America|author=Luke Vincent Lockwood|chapter=XI. Clocks. Part 5|year=1913|quote=Figure 848 shows another tall clock in a lacquer case, the property of Dr. Edward L. Oatman, of Brooklyn. The spandrels are in the form of scrolls, and on the dial in the dome is engraved "White Matlack New York," who worked in New York from 1769 to 1775.}}

'''Warner "William" McCary''' (c. 1811 – after 1854){{citation |last= Horn |first= Patrick E. |title= Summary of A Sketch of the Life of Okah Tubbee, (Called) William Chubbee, Son of the Head Chief, Mosholeh Tubbee, of the Choctaw Nation of Indians |year= 2004 |work= Documenting the American South: North American Slave Narratives |publisher= University Library, [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] |url= http://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/tubbee/summary.html |accessdate= 2013-02-18 }} was an [[African American]] convert to [[Mormonism]] who was expelled from [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church) in 1847 for claiming to be a [[prophet]]. Some researchers have suggested that McCary's actions led to the LDS Church's [[Blacks and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints#Racial restriction policy|subsequent policy]] of not allowing people of [[Black people|black]] [[Africa]]n descent to hold the [[Priesthood (LDS Church)|priesthood]] or participate in [[Temple (LDS Church)|temple]] [[Ordinance (Latter Day Saints)|ordinances]].{{citation |first= Patrick A. |last= Polk |title='A Negro Preacher': The Worlds of Elijah Ables |journal= Journal of Mormon History |volume= 35 |issue= 3 |date=Summer 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170418060136/http://www.uvu.edu/religiousstudies/docs/2017_msc/russell_stevenson.pdf |url=http://www.uvu.edu/religiousstudies/docs/2017_msc/russell_stevenson.pdf|archive-date=18 April 2017|pages= 228-234 }} ==Background== He was born as Warner McCary in [[Natchez, Mississippi]] around 1810 or 1811 to an [[African American slave]] named Francis, or "Franky", and her master, a [[White people|white]] [[carpenter]] from [[Pennsylvania]] named James McCary. They also had two older children, Kitty and Robert. Upon James McCary's death around 1813, his [[Will (law)|will]] emancipated Franky and the older children but declared Warner and his future offspring to "be held as slaves during all and each of their lives" in the service of his mother and siblings.{{citation |last= O'Donovan |first= Connell |contribution= 'I would confine them to their own species': LDS Historical Rhetoric & Praxis Regarding Marriage Between Whites and Blacks |date= March 28, 2009 |title= [[Sunstone Symposium]] West |location= Cupertino, CA |contribution-url= http://www.connellodonovan.com/black_white_marriage.html |accessdate= 2013-02-18 }} In 1836 he escaped Natchez on a riverboat and went to [[New Orleans]], where he worked at Leeds Foundry until 1840, as well as an occasional musician and cigar vendor. Around this time he married a white Mormon woman, Lucy Stanton Bassett, who claimed to be a [[Native Americans of the United States|Native American]] woman named Laah Ceil. She claimed her mother was [[Delaware Indian]] and father was [[Mohawk nation|Mohawk]]. In his youth, Warner McCary had begun using other names, including James Warner, William McCary, and Cary. He eventually adopted over a dozen aliases, many of which were Native American, including William Chubbee, William Chubbee King, Julius McCary, William McChubby, Okah Tubee, James Warner, and War'ne'wis Ke'ho'ke Chubbee. According to Connell O'Donovan, McCary used these alternate identities "to both reinvent and reimagine his unhappy childhood, and to make his way and a living as an escaped slave in a white-dominant world." Presenting himself as a Native American, McCary was helped in 1843 by local whites to get a permit as a [[free person of color]] in Mississippi. When he left in 1844, he toured various [[frontier]] and [[Eastern United States|eastern]] cities as a musician and lecturer. During this time he briefly joined with Mormonism where he sparked racial controversy. ==Conversion to Mormonism== McCary arrived in [[Nauvoo, Illinois]] in late 1845. He claimed he was a half-African American and half-Native American named Okah Tubbee and the "lost" son of [[Choctaw]] chief [[Mushulatubbee]]. McCary was also known as a skilled [[Ventriloquism|ventriloquist]] and musician. {{citation |first= Newell G. |last= Bringhurst |year= 1981 |title= Saints, Slaves, and Blacks: The Changing Place of Black People within Mormonism |location= Westport, Connecticut |publisher= Greenwood Press |isbn= |oclc= }} In [[Council Bluffs]], [[Iowa]] in February 1846, he was [[Baptism (LDS Church)|baptized]] into the LDS Church by [[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|Apostle]] [[Orson Hyde]], and he probably was ordained to the [[Melchizedek priesthood (Latter Day Saints)|Melchizedek priesthood]]. Around this time, McCary also married Lucy Stanton, a white daughter of Daniel Stanton, a former [[high councilor]] and [[stake president]]. In the winter of 1846–1847, he joined the [[Latter Day Saint]]s in [[Winter Quarters, Nebraska]]. {{citation |first= Larry G. |last= Murphy |authorlink2= J. Gordon Melton |first2= J. Gordon |last2= Melton |first3= Gary L. |last3= Ward |year= 1993 |title= Encyclopedia of African American Religions |location= New York |publisher= Garland Publishing |pages= 471–472 |isbn= |oclc= }} ==Prophet and excommunication== While in Winter Quarters, McCary began claiming powers of [[prophesy]] and transfiguration — he claimed to have the power to appear as various [[Bible|biblical]] and [[Book of Mormon]] figures. In early 1847, McCary was [[Excommunication (LDS Church)|excommunicated]] from the church for [[apostasy]] and expelled from Winter Quarters. Shortly after his expulsion, Hyde preached a sermon against McCary and his claims. McCary settled a short distance away and began attracting some Winter Quarters followers to his own brand of Mormonism. He instituted [[plural marriage]] among his followers, and had himself [[Sealing (Latter Day Saints)|sealed]] to several [[White people|white]] wives. ==Effect on LDS Church policy== McCary's behavior angered many of the Latter Day Saints in Winter Quarters. Researchers have stated that his marriages to his white wives "played an important role in pushing the Mormon leadership into an anti-Black position" and may have prompted [[Brigham Young]] to institute the priesthood and temple ban on black people.{{cite journal |last= O'Donovan |first= Connell |url= |title= The Mormon Priesthood Ban & Elder Q. Walker Lewis: ‘An example for his more whiter brethren to follow’ |journal= [[John Whitmer Historical Association Journal]] |year= 2006 }} ([http://people.ucsc.edu/~odonovan/elder_walker_lewis.html Online reprint] with author updates) A statement from Young to McCary in March 1847 suggested that up until that point, race had nothing to do with priesthood eligibility"Its nothing to do with the blood for [from] one blood has God made all flesh, we have to repent [to] regain what we av lost — we av one of the best Elders an African in Lowell [referring to [[Walker Lewis]] ]."
{{citation |title= Brigham Young Papers |date= March 26, 1847 |publisher= LDS Church Archives |location= Salt Lake City, Utah }}{{full|date=August 2014}} and the earliest known statement about blacks being restricted from the priesthood from any Mormon leader was made by Apostle [[Parley P. Pratt]] a month after McCary was expelled from Winter Quarters. Speaking of McCary, Pratt stated that he "was a black man with the blood of Ham in him which linege was cursed as regards the priesthood".{{citation |title= General Minutes |date= April 25, 1847 |publisher= LDS Church Archives |location= Salt Lake City, Utah}}{{full|date=August 2014}} After Brigham Young instigated the priesthood and temple ban in 1847, the LDS Church generally did not allow men of black African descent to hold the priesthood again until 1978. ==See also== *[[Black people and Mormonism]] *[[Blacks and the Latter Day Saint movement]] *[[Official Declaration—2]] ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book | author = Tubbee | first = Okah | title = A Sketch of the Life of Okah Tubbee, (Called) William Chubbee, Son of the Head Chief, Mosholeh Tubbee, of the Choctaw Nation of Indians | year = 1852 | publisher = H. Stephens | location = [[Toronto]] | url = http://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/tubbee/menu.html }} *{{cite book | author = Pulley Hudson | first = Angela | title = Real Native Genius: How an Ex-Slave and a White Mormon Became Famous Indians | year = 2015 | publisher = University of North Carolina Press | location = Chapel Hill, NC | url = http://uncpress.unc.edu/browse/book_detail?title_id=3672 }} {{DEFAULTSORT:McCary, William}} [[Category:1810s births]] [[Category:African-American Latter Day Saints]] [[Category:African-American religious leaders]] [[Category:Converts to Mormonism]] [[Category:American Latter Day Saint leaders]] [[Category:Mormonism and race]] [[Category:People excommunicated by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] [[Category:People from Natchez, Mississippi]] [[Category:Prophets in Mormonism]] [[Category:Religious figures of the indigenous peoples of North America]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:Latter Day Saints from Mississippi]] [[Category:Latter Day Saints from Illinois]]
